title: Anila Baig: We're going blind to the dangers of ogling a screen
text:

When I was little I would ­huddle up close to the telly, much to the ­annoyance of my parents who would complain that I would end up going blind.

“But,” I would whine, “I can’t see it properly in the first place – that’s why I have to sit near it.”

Needless to say I ended up wearing jam-jar bottomed ­spectacles which were a source of great embarrassment at school.

But, at least back in my day, television, like food, was not unlimited. Just as you would get three square meals with no snacking in between, there were also regulated TV times.

We would be allowed to watch one programme then it was turned off.

My friend’s parents even kept their television covered with a cloth when it wasn’t in use, like a shroud, only to be unveiled for important ­occasions like Muhammad Ali fights and the Nine O’Clock News.

Back then it was unthinkable that you would just sit in a stupor staring at the telly from dusk till dawn.

What would we have watched anyway? We only had three channels back then and BBC2 was too boring for words.

(Image: Valentin Wolf/imageBROKER/REX/Shutterstock)

But now this constant bombardment is causing an epidemic of short-sightedness and opticians are urging parents to take action before it is too late. There is predicted to be a surge in the numbers of people who will become blind or visually impaired in the future as a direct result of too much screen time.

The findings have been revealed by the International Myopia Institute, and there was also a study of the ­lifestyles of almost 9,000 youngsters by Dr Clare Quigley, an ophthalmologist based at Galway University Hospital, Ireland, who found that myopia – short-­sightedness – was not genetic.

Instead a direct link between myopia and sedentary lifestyles was found.

She said: “Time outdoors, especially during your early ­childhood, is protective against myopia.”

At the moment around 20% of under-16s are short-sighted compared to just 7.2% back in the 1960s, and the situation is getting worse.

By 2050 myopia rates will go up to 50%. Apparently it is very rare in nomadic communities.

And it isn’t just eyesight which is suffering. Youngsters are also racking up huge bills playing online games. We must open our eyes to this epidemic.

We need to put down the iPads and iPhones and consider our actual eyes.

After all, we only get one pair.
description: Children who are inactive and don't go outdoors enough are more likely to suffer short-sightedness, studies are revealing
